messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 59 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Trust Your Robots! Predictive Uncertainty Estimation of Neural Networks with Sparse Gaussian Processes

Paper Abstract: Abstract This paper presents a probabilistic framework to obtain both reliable and fast uncertainty estimates for predictions with Deep Neural Networks (DNNs). Our main contribution is a practical and principled combination of DNNs with sparse Gaussian Processes (GPs). We prove theoretically that DNNs can be seen as a special case of sparse GPs, namely mixtures of GP experts (MoE-GP), and we devise a learning algorithm that brings the derived theory into practice. In experiments from two different robotic tasks – inverse dynamics of a manipulator and object detection on a micro-aerial vehicle (MAV) – we show the effectiveness of our approach in terms of predictive uncertainty, improved scalability, and run-time efficiency on a Jetson TX2. We thus argue that our approach can pave the way towards reliable and fast robot learning systems with uncertainty awareness.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 59 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 59"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Probabilistic robotics",
        "Introspective Classification for Robot Perception",
        "Dropout as a bayesian approximation: Representing model uncertainty in deep learning",
        "Simple and scalable predictive uncertainty estimation using deep ensembles",
        "On calibration of modern neural networks",
        "Functional varitional bayesian neural networks",
        "Semantic categorization of outdoor scenes with uncertainty estimates using multi-class gaussian process classification",
        "Adaptive mixtures of local experts",
        "Mixtures of gaussian processes",
        "Neural tangent kernel: Convergence and generalization in neural networks",
        "ARDEA - An MAV with skills for future planetary missions",
        "Introspective perception: Learning to predict failures in vision systems",
        "Failing to learn: autonomously identifying perception failures for self-driving cars",
        "Learn from experience: probabilistic prediction of perception performance to avoid failure",
        "Safe visual navigation via deep learning and novelty detection",
        "Identifying unknown instances for autonomous driving",
        "Introspective robot perception using smoothed predictions from bayesian neural networks",
        "Bayesod: A bayesian approach for uncertainty estimation in deep object detectors",
        "A probabilistic challenge for object detection",
        "A survey of uncertainty in deep neural networks",
        "Visual-inertial telepresence for aerial manipulation",
        "Towards autonomous stratospheric flight: A generic global system identification framework for fixed-wing platforms",
        "Evidential deep learning to quantify classification uncertainty",
        "Scalable uncertainty for computer vision with functional variational inference",
        "Bayesian deep ensembles via the neural tangent kernel",
        "Exploring the uncertainty properties of neural networks’ implicit priors in the infinite-width limit",
        "Information-based objective functions for active data selection",
        "Sampling-free epistemic uncertainty estimation using approximated variance propagation",
        "’in-between’uncertainty in bayesian neural networks",
        "Priors for infinite networks",
        "Deep neural networks as gaussian processes",
        "Approximate inference turns deep networks into gaussian processes",
        "Efficient Computation of Gaussian Process Regression for Large Spatial Data Sets by Patching Local Gaussian Processes",
        "Patchwork kriging for large-scale gaussian process regression",
        "Benchmarking the neural linear model for regression",
        "Neural linear models with functional gaussian process priors",
        "Pattern recognition and machine learning",
        "Gaussian Processes for Machine Learning",
        "Deep kernel learning",
        "When gaussian process meets big data: A review of scalable gps",
        "Hard mixtures of experts for large scale weakly supervised vision",
        "Incremental local gaussian regression",
        "Aleatoric and epistemic uncertainty in machine learning: An introduction to concepts and methods",
        "Constant-time predictive distributions for gaussian processes",
        "Uncertainty estimation with infinitesimal jackknife, its distribution and mean-field approximation",
        "Non-parametric calibration for classification",
        "A scalable laplace approximation for neural networks",
        "Bayesian optimization meets laplace approximation for robotic introspection",
        "Estimating model uncertainty of neural networks in sparse information form",
        "Learning multiplicative interactions with bayesian neural networks for visual-inertial odometry",
        "K-means clustering via principal component analysis",
        "Kernel k-means: spectral clustering and normalized cuts",
        "Approximate kernel k-means: Solution to large scale kernel clustering",
        "Fast sparse gaussian process methods: The informative vector machine",
        "Driven learning for driving: How introspection improves semantic mapping",
        "The arches space-analogue demonstration mission: towards heterogeneous teams of autonomous robots for collaborative scientific sampling in planetary exploration",
        "End-to-end object detection with transformers",
        "Detecting extrapolation with local ensembles",
        "Sketching curvature for efficient out-of-distribution detection for deep neural networks"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 59 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Trust Your Robots! Predictive Uncertainty Estimation of Neural Networks with Sparse Gaussian Processes, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
